name: @eng3d
text:
I use AI to assist me in the code. At first, it looks great but the efficacy is around 50%, so the pipeline is reduced as:
a) AI suggests a code
b) check manually if the code is right.
c) if the code is right then use it.
d) if the code is not right then, don't use it, or correct it.
Since b) is tedious in the long run then, AI tends to be more of a distraction and a waste of time than a real help.
Also, AI works 50% with boilerplate code, it fails epically for everything else.
CleanedText: I use AI to assist me in the code. At first, it looks great, but the efficacy is around 50 , The pipeline is reduced as a AI suggests a code b check manually if the code is right. see if the code is right then use it. d if the code is not right then, do not use it, or correct it. Since b is tedious in the long run then, AI tends to be more of a distraction and a waste of time than a real help. Also, AI works 50 with boilerplate code, it fails apically for everything else.

name: @ThomasJohansson-mo5gf
text: I think it is too early to say that AI as such is causing layoffs. It is rather the perception of AI that people have (and which I believe will turn out to be a hype) that is being used as an excuse for laying off people. The companies probably have too many employees, and especially many woke, lazy and troublesome people, whom they want to get rid of, and they're using AI as an excuse.

name: @vladimirofsvalbard9477
text:
People are diagnosing this issue incorrectly from my opinion and perhaps it's intentional.

They claim that around 0.01% of tech jobs are including 'AI' in their job description titles. So they conclude that AI is not the reason that people are losing their jobs, considering that very few jobs entertain the necessity to work with those software programs.

You don't need to create a job that includes AI programming for every 2, 3, or even 10 jobs. It's more or less 1 in 10,000 at this rate.

The whole idea of AI is that an 'already existing program' can be put on a single software engineers itinerary so that he can now ensure that the workload of hundreds or thousands of ex-colleagues is being completely in a short period of time.

In other words, profits!
CleanedText: People are diagnosing this issue incorrectly from my opinion and perhaps it .intentional. They claim that around 0.01 of tech jobs are including AI in their job description titles. So they conclude that AI is not the reason that people are losing their jobs, considering that very few jobs entertain the necessity to work with those software programs. You do not need to create a job that includes AI programming for every 2, 3, or even 10 jobs. It .more or less 1 in 10,000 at this rate. The whole idea of AI is that analready existing program can be put on a single software engineers itinerary. That he can now ensure that the workload of hundreds or thousands of ex colleagues is being completely in a short period of time. In other words, profit is!

name: @thebrandonbeatty
text: The one question no one asks is WHO will be the customer - Even if the wealth gap continues to increase - Apple is only as valuable because it gets its phones to customers hands. At this rate there will be no customers or only very few - Essentially defeating the purpose of AI. Every year I've had to reduce my spending and this year its down to utility bills and raw food ingredients in bulk. Everyone needs to stop patronizing these large corps and return to smaller community living. We can be wealthy amongst ourselves without government and without big corps. Markets are people, not AI and certainly not machines.

name: @MegUSN52
text:
Good time to work for the federal govt. Our software is always older than that of private sector businesses/organizations. Due to National Security concerns, I doubt the govt. will ever be fully AI.

I am not scared of AI. All consumers have been using "ai" for several years without realizing it was "ai". Jobs have changed for centuries. You either embrace it or get left behind. This is nothing new. Still, I'm glad I only have six more years until I retire, and for once, I'm glad I work for the govt. One thing for sure, I hope they heavily regulate AI and they better do it soon before people start using it more for evil than for good.

name: @jamesgravil9162
text:
"and you have to do this your entire career."

What happens when you get into your 40s, 50s and 60s and find yourself competing with 20-somethings who are fitter, sharper and more up-to-date than you? You might work harder than everyone in your department, but that's no guarantee you'll keep your job. If you work in retail, it might make sense from the business' point-of-view to have someone young and pretty instead. Maybe the person doing the hiring just fancies the 21-year-old more than they do you, even if they're lazy and unqualified.
